I've written about how that news was spun at the time, and played out since. I will, in fact, get back to those biologists. In my news story, I stressed (the equivalent of my warning about "single-study syndrome") the tentative nature of the finding:

If the analysis holds up, it will be the first to link recent climate changes to the spread of a fungus lethal to frogs and salamanders and their kin. The chytrid fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, has devastated amphibian communities in many parts of the world over the last several decades.

But experts on amphibian disease and ecology are divided over the finding, which is being published today in the journal Nature. Several scientists criticized the paper yesterday, saying it glossed over significant sources of uncertainty; others said it was important evidence that warming caused by humans was already harming wildlife. Climate scientists have linked most of the recent rise in the earth's average temperature to the buildup of greenhouse emissions from smokestacks and tailpipes.

"When we first looked at the paleoclimatic data, I was struck by the small cooling of the ocean,” Schmittner said. “On average, the ocean was only about two degrees (Celsius) cooler than it is today, yet the planet was completely different – huge ice sheets over North America and northern Europe, more sea ice and snow, different vegetation, lower sea levels and more dust in the air.

“Hence, drastic changes over land can be expected,” he said. “However, our study implies that we still have time to prevent that from happening, if we make a concerted effort to change course soon.”

Dear Andy,

I must disagree with you and Gavin Schmidt regarding the importance of climate sensitivity to public policy.

The entire CAGW enterprise is premised on the assumption that climate sensitivity is high, and that consequently climate change will be too rapid for the biosphere (and humankind) to adapt to it.

If that assumption is wrong, and climate sensitivity to added CO2 is actually low, or even just non-catastrophic, then the whole topic of "anthropogenic climate change" becomes a mole-hill instead of a mountain.

The fundamental concept of a carbon tax as a method to prevent climate change assumes that climate sensitivity is high. If climate sensitivity is low, the CO2 emissions discouraged by a carbon tax will have no effect on climate change.

Consequently the narrative of potential climate catastrophe DEMANDS perceived risks of high climate sensitivity significant enough to make the whole concept policy-relevant.

The reason Lindzen, Spencer and Christy are abhorred by Establishment climate modelers like Schmidt is that they postulate a low climate sensitivity. This makes the whole "problem" fade into a non-problem.

Now comes Schmittner et al whose calculations chop off the extreme high "tail" of the possible climate sensitivity distribution. If true, the worst possible outcomes postulated by Gore, Rahmsdorf and Romm must come off the table when we debate policy.

Schmidt must know that climate sensitivity is the linchpin of the whole CAGW debate.

The entire system qualifies quality applicants primarily based on the amount of credit they have taken out and paid off on time. This completely misses individuals who have little need for debt outside of large ticket items. For instance, an individual carrying only one credit card and a mortgage which are always paid on time are unlikely to have a stellar credit rating.

How can it be that a well capitalized individual who rarely needs credit does not have a superior credit rating?
